{{Short description|American musician and painter}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Alan Vega | image = Suicide(band)crop.jpg | caption = Vega (right) with [[Martin Rev]], 1988 | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Alan Bermowitz | alias = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1938|6|23}} | birth_place = [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2016|7|16|1938|6|23}} | death_place = [[New York City]], New York, U.S. | instrument = Vocalist | genre = [[Protopunk]], [[electronic music|electronic]], [[experimental rock|experimental]], [[electro-punk]], [[minimalist music|minimalist]], [[industrial music|industrial]], [[synthpop]] | occupation = Musician, sculptor, [[painter (artist)|painter]] | years_active = 1966–2016 | label = [[ZE Records]] | associated_acts = [[Suicide (band)|Suicide]], [[The Sisterhood]] }}
'''Alan Bermowitz''' (June 23, 1938 – July 16, 2016), known professionally as '''Alan Vega''', was an American vocalist and visual artist, primarily known for his work with the [[electronic music|electronic]] [[protopunk]] duo [[Suicide (band)|Suicide]].
== Life and career ==
Alan Bermowitz was raised in [[Bensonhurst, Brooklyn|Bensonhurst]], Brooklyn. Until the announcement of the 70th birthday release of his recordings in 2008, Vega was widely thought to have been ten years younger; the 2005 book ''Suicide: No Compromise'' lists 1948 as his birth year and quotes a 1998 interview in which Vega talks about watching [[Elvis Presley]] on ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'' (1956) as a "little kid".<ref name="Suicide: No Compromise"/> A 1983 ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' article refers to him as a 35-year-old,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/668650772.html?dids=668650772:668650772&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Aug+11%2C+1983&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=ALAN+VEGA%3A+MELLOWING+ON+AMERICA&pqatl=google|title=ALAN VEGA: MELLOWING ON AMERICA|date=August 11, 1983|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=2010-05-06}}</ref> and several other sources also list 1948 as his birthdate.<ref name="Buckley">Buckley, Peter (2003) ''The Rough Guide to Rock'', Rough Guides, {{ISBN|978-1-84353-105-0}}, p. 1131</ref><ref name="Thompson">Thompson, Dave (2000) ''Alternative Rock'', Miller Freeman Books, {{ISBN|0-87930-607-6}}, p. 667</ref> Two 2009 articles confirmed his 1938 birth date, one in ''[[Le Monde]]'' about the Lyon exhibit<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archives.lemonde.fr/gop/archives_23/0,0-0,37-1085390,0.html|title=La crucifixion, la mort et l'extase selon Alan Vega|publisher="Le Monde"|date=June 5, 2009|accessdate=2010-05-06}}</ref> and one in the magazine ''[[Rolling Stone]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://popnewsdaily.com/11775/the-feelies-dirty-three-with-nick-cave-revisit-classic-albums-at-all-tomorrow%E2%80%99s-parties.htm|title=The Feelies, Dirty Three With Nick Cave Revisit Classic Albums at All Tomorrow's Parties|publisher=Rolling Stone|date=September 12, 2009|accessdate=2010-05-09}} {{Dead link|date=November 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Vega also long claimed to be Catholic due to his mother's [[Puerto Ricans|Puerto Rican]] ancestry. Although themes of [[Catholicism]] were important to his lyrics and visual art over the years, in a 2008 interview with ''[[The Jewish Chronicle]]'' he admitted he lied about his own religious upbringing to "fuel the myth".<ref name=TJC >[http://www.thejc.com/node/6842 "Suicide: How the godfathers of punk kept the faith"], Paul Lester, ''The Jewish Chronicle'', October 10, 2008.</ref>
In the mid 1960s, he attended [[Brooklyn College]] where he studied both physics and fine art under [[Ad Reinhardt]] and [[Kurt Seligmann]]<ref name=copeland>{{cite book |title=Alan Suicide Vega – Infinite Mercy? Let U$ Pray! |last=Copeland |first=Mathieu |year=2010 |publisher=Les presses du réel |location=[[Dijon]], France |isbn=978-2-84066-379-9}}</ref> and graduated in 1967.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:YjZPxLU14fMJ:www.hunter.cuny.edu/chest/Images/spr09%2520BkC%2520Mag.pdf+BC+MAGAZINE+SPRING+2009&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEEShxo_EzxxL90zrzusxSllbAJ17sMJ9-E5gOIGcDyZ267z9KIos0QWv9Q0j8Cq61Bq596WtpJ7ZVrCpZsCOWo6IZuOxa9wUaMblTuNzwgl3YF7cLklACOWIDH3iIP2SVp2s6g1nh&sig=AHIEtbSeEfY1OIRmhUfvrRJ1NldHAIImyA |title=Alumni Newsmakers |author= |date=Spring 2009 |work= |publisher=Brooklyn College Magazine |accessdate=May 10, 2010}}</ref> In the 1960s, he became involved with the [[Art Workers' Coalition]], a radical artists group that harassed museums and once barricaded the [[Museum of Modern Art]].<ref name=reynolds>{{cite news |first=Simon |last=Reynolds |authorlink=Simon Reynolds |title=Suicide Watch |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2002-01-29/news/suicide-watch/ |publisher=[[Village Voice]] |date= |accessdate=2010-05-09}}</ref> In 1969, funding from the [[New York State Council on the Arts]] made possible the founding of MUSEUM: A Project of Living Artists—an artist-run 24-hour multimedia gallery at 729 Broadway <ref>{{cite news |title=display ad |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xuwjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=K4wDAAAAIBAJ&dq=project-of-living-artists&pg=5952%2C2139437 |date=September 25, 1969|publisher= [[Village Voice]] |accessdate=2010-05-10}}</ref> in Manhattan. Calling himself Alan Suicide, he graduated from painting to light sculptures,<ref group="note">"I started as a painter. The first time I did a light piece was when I was working on a very big purple painting. There was one light bulb in the room and as I walked around I noticed how the painting acquired different aspects. I wanted it to be one color so I said, "Fuck this, man!" I took the light out of the ceiling and really stuck it on the painting." Alan Vega, 1993 – 100,000 Watts of Fat City Anna Polerica.</ref> many of which were constructed of electronic debris. He gained a residency at the [[OK Harris Gallery]] in [[SoHo]] where he continued to exhibit until 1975.<ref name=copeland /> [[Barbara Gladstone]] continued to show his work well into the 1980s.
Seeing [[The Stooges]] perform at the [[New York State Pavilion]] in August 1969 was an epiphany for Vega.<ref group="note">"It showed me you didn't have to do static artworks, you could create situations, do something environmental. That's what got me moving more intensely in the direction of doing music. Compared with Iggy, whatever I was doing as an artist felt insignificant." Reynolds, Village Voice.January 29, 2002</ref> In 1966, he met and befriended [[Martin Rev]]erby. Together, the two began experimenting with music and formed the band [[Suicide (band)|Suicide]] along with guitarist Paul Liebgott. The group played twice at MUSEUM before moving on to the OK Harris Gallery. Calling himself "Nasty Cut", he used the terms "Punk Music" and "Punk Music Mass" in flyers to describe their music,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fromthearchives.org/av_mr/chronology.html |title=SuicideChronology |accessdate=2010-05-10 |publisher=From The Archives| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100614080703/http://www.fromthearchives.org/av_mr/chronology.html| archivedate= June 14, 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> which he adopted from an article by [[Lester Bangs]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.98bowery.com/punkyears/punk-art-catalogue-section-four.php |title=Punk Art Catalogue – Section IV: Suicide, Bad Boys, Tattoos |accessdate=2010-03-10 |last=Miller |first=Marc H. |date=April 20, 2009 |work=1978 Punk Art Exhibit |publisher=98Bowery.com| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100330100042/http://www.98bowery.com/punkyears/punk-art-catalogue-section-four.php| archivedate= March 30, 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> In 1971 the group dropped Paul Liebgott and added Mari Reverby on drums,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fromthearchives.com/av_mr/chronology.html |title=Suicide Chronology |author= |date= |work= |publisher=FromTheArchives.org |accessdate=May 10, 2010}}</ref> though she didn't play in their live performances. With Bermowitz finally settling on Alan Suicide as a working name, they began to play music venues. Suicide went on to perform at the [[Mercer Arts Center]], [[Max's Kansas City]], [[CBGB]] and ultimately, achieve international recognition.
In 1980, Vega released his eponymous first solo record. It defined the frantic [[rockabilly]] style that he would use in his solo work for the next several years, with the song "Jukebox Babe" becoming a hit single in France. In 1985, he released the more commercially viable ''Just a Million Dreams,'' but was dropped from his record label after its release. The album originally was set to be produced by [[Ric Ocasek]] as a follow-up to the critically acclaimed ''[[Saturn Strip]]'' (1983), but production switched over to [[Chris Lord-Alge]] and Vega ran into several difficulties during the recording sessions.<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r59094|pure_url=yes}}|last=Valdivia|first=Victor W|title=Just a Million Dreams review|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=2010-04-26}}</ref> The album eschewed many of Vega's experimental traits in favor of power pop songs and he later lamented, "They took all my songs and turned them into God knows what."<ref name="Suicide: No Compromise">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=J2w35kE7O0AC&lpg=PA16&dq=No%20Compromise%20alan%20Vega%201948&pg=PA16#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Suicide: No Compromise |publisher=Google Books |date= |accessdate=2010-05-11|isbn=9780946719716 |year=2004 }}</ref>
Vega teamed up with Martin Rev and Ric Ocasek again in the late eighties to produce and release the third Suicide album, ''A Way of Life'' (1988). Visual artist [[Stefan Roloff]] produced a music video for the song ''Dominic Christ'' which was released by [[Wax Trax! Records]] and Suicide went overseas to promote the album by performing the song "Surrender" in Paris which was aired on French television. Shortly thereafter, Vega met future wife and music partner Elizabeth Lamere while piecing together sound experiments that would evolve into his fifth solo album, ''Deuce Avenue'' (1990). ''Deuce Avenue'' marked his return to minimalist electronic music, similar to his work with Suicide, in which he combined drum machines and effects with free-form prose. Over the next decade he would release several more solo records as well as perform with Suicide.
In 2002, art dealer [[Jeffrey Deitch]] tracked him down after a couple of his young gallery employees "gushed" over a Suicide gig at the NYC [[Knitting Factory]].<ref name="Brooklyn">{{cite web|last1=Klingman|first1=Jeff|title=Punk, 77: At Home With Alan Vega|url=http://www.bkmag.com/2015/12/03/punk-77-at-home-with-alan-vega/|publisher=[[Brooklyn (magazine)|Brooklyn]]|accessdate=30 March 2016|date=December 3, 2015}}</ref> Vega constructed ''Collision Drive'', an exhibition of sculptures combining light with found objects and crucifixes.<ref name=reynolds />
Vega's tenth solo album, ''Station'', was released on [[Blast First]] Records in 2007 and was described by his colleagues as "his hardest, heaviest album for quite a while, all self-played and produced."<ref>{{cite web|title=Live|url=http://www.slimsmith.com/alanvega/|work=Alan Vega|publisher=Slim Smith|accessdate=December 21, 2013|date=December 2006|quote=The new live set is based around Alan's new album, "Station", his hardest, heaviest album for quite a while, all self-played and produced.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130117062553/http://www.slimsmith.com/alanvega/|archivedate=January 17, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In 2008, British label [[Blast First|Blast First Petite]] released a limited edition Suicide 6-CD [[box set]] and monthly tribute series of 10" Vinyl EP's, to mark the occasion of Alan Vega's 70th birthday<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mvremix.com/rock_blogs/2008/06/24/alan-vega-turns-60-years-old-suicide-box-set-and-single-series-set-for-release-major-artists-pay-tribute-to-suicidevega-in-year-long-monthly-series-of-limited-edition-of-10-vinyl-eps-and-dow/ |title=Alan Vega Turns 60- Years Old/Box Set |author=Paul Smith |year=2008 |work= |publisher=MV Remix Rock |accessdate=April 20, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Musicians who contributed to the tribute series included [[The Horrors]], [[Lydia Lunch]], [[Primal Scream]], and [[Miss Kittin]].<ref name="nmeprimalscream">{{cite web | url=http://www.nme.com/news/primal-scream/42699| title=Primal Scream cover Suicide for new single | work = [[NME]]| publisher=[[Time Inc.]] | date = February 11, 2009| accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref>
In 2009, the Museum of Contemporary Art in [[Lyon]], France, mounted ''Infinite Mercy'' – a major retrospective exhibit of Vega's art, curated by Mathieu Copeland.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mac-lyon.com/mac/sections/en/exhibitions/2009/alan_vega |title=Alan Vega, Infinite Mercy |accessdate=2010-04-26 |publisher=Musée d'art contemporain de Lyon}}</ref> This included the screening of two short documentary films: ''Alan Vega'' (2000) by Christian Eudeline, and ''Autour d’Alan Vega (extraits)'' (1998) by Hugues Peyret.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mac-lyon.com/mac/sections/fr/publics/rendez-vous/archives/2009/autour_de_lexpositi/ |title=Documentaires sur Alan Vega |accessdate=2010-04-26 |publisher=Musée d'art contemporain de Lyon |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714011800/http://www.mac-lyon.com/mac/sections/fr/publics/rendez-vous/archives/2009/autour_de_lexpositi/ |archivedate=July 14, 2011 }}</ref>
In 2012, Vega suffered a [[stroke]]. That, and problems with his knees, led him to focus on less physically demanding art, such as painting, rather than music. He continued to live in downtown New York City.<ref name="Brooklyn"/>
In 2016, Vega made a small return to music by contributing vocals to the song "Tangerine" on French pop veteran singer [[Christophe (singer)|Christophe]]'s album ''Les Vestiges du chaos''.<ref name="vestiges_booklet">{{cite AV media notes |title=Les Vestiges du chaos |others=[[Christophe (singer)|Christophe]] |year= 2016 |type=album booklet |publisher=[[Universal Music Records|Universal Music Publishing France]] |id=478 221 4}}</ref>
In 2017, Alan Vega's final album "IT" was released posthumously on July 14 on [[Fader Label|Fader]]. The album was produced by Alan Vega, Liz Lamere, Perkin Barnes and [[Jared Artaud]] of New York City band [[The Vacant Lots]]. The album cover and inner sleeves featured Vega's original artwork.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://pitchfork.com/news/74099-sucides-alan-vega-posthumous-album-it-announced-new-song-dtm-shared-listen/ |title=Suicide's Alan Vega Posthumous Album IT |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Pitchfork.com |accessdate=June 12, 2017}}</ref> Two posthumous art shows "Dream Baby Dream" at [[Deitch Projects|Deitch Gallery]] and "Keep IT Alive" at [[Invisible-Exports]] exhibited Alan Vega's work in New York City.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/23/arts/design/alan-vega-ignored-the-art-world-it-wont-return-the-favor.html |title=Alan Vega Ignored The Art World It Won't Return The Favor |author= |date= |work= |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=June 23, 2017}}</ref>
==Religious views==
On Vega's religious views, he was raised in the Jewish faith, but declared himself to be Catholic for many years due to his mother's upbringing. When asked about God he stated, "I distrust the name 'God' but, yes, I do believe in a higher power, God is in all of us," he says, before deciding: "There is an immense power. There has to be." He also shared the views of [[Spinoza]], the pantheist philosopher.<ref>{{cite web|title=Suicide: How the godfathers of punk kept the faith|url=http://www.thejc.com/arts/music/suicide-how-godfathers-punk-kept-faith|publisher=The Jewish Chronicle Online|author=Paul Lester|date=October 10, 2008|quote=Vega is similarly ambivalent. He alludes to the "miraculous" nature of his career with Suicide and fateful meeting with Rev, begging the question – does he believe in a higher power? "I distrust the name 'God' but, yes, I do believe in a higher power," he says. He adds that he shares the rationalist stance of Spinoza, the 17th-century Jewish philosopher and "pantheist theologian". "God is in all of us," he says, before deciding: "There is an immense power. There has to be."}}</ref>
==Death==
Vega died in his sleep on July 16, 2016 at the age of 78. His death was announced by musician and radio host [[Henry Rollins]], who shared an official statement from Vega's family on his website.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Kreps |first=Daniel |title=Alan Vega, Suicide Singer and Punk Icon, Dead at 78 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/alan-vega-suicide-singer-and-punk-icon-dead-at-78-w429537 |journal=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=17 July 2016 |issn=0035-791X}}</ref>

{{For|a Greek mythological figure|Alpheus (mythology)}}
{{Infobox river | name = Alfeios | image = Alfeios map.jpg | image_caption = | source1_location = [[Peloponnese]] | mouth_location = [[Ionian Sea]] | mouth_coordinates = {{coord|37|36|45|N|21|27|6|E|display=inline,title}} | subdivision_type1 = Country | subdivision_name1 = [[Greece]] | length = {{convert|110|km|abbr=on}} | source1_elevation = | discharge1_avg = | basin_size = | tributaries_right = [[Lousios]], [[Ladon (river)|Ladon]], [[Erymanthos (river)|Erymanthos]] }} '''Alfeiós''' ({{lang-el|Αλφειός}}, also romanized as '''Alpheus''', '''Alpheios''') is the longest river in the [[Peloponnese]], in [[Greece]]. The river is {{convert|110|km}} long,<ref>[http://www.statistics.gr/documents/20181/1515741/GreeceInFigures_2018Q1_EN.pdf/e90e9c60-ed92-40a7-a1e0-9a58d542d596 Greece in Figures January - March 2018], p. 12</ref> flowing through the regional units of [[Arcadia]] and [[Elis (regional unit)|Elis]]. Its source is near the village [[Valtetsi|Dorizas]], about halfway between [[Tripoli, Greece|Tripoli]] and [[Megalopolis, Greece|Megalopoli]] in the highlands of [[Arcadia]]. It flows southwest toward Megalopoli, where it has been diverted around open pit [[lignite]] mines. At [[Thoknia]] it receives its right tributary [[Elissonas (Alfeios)|Elissonas]], and continues north towards [[Karytaina]]. Below Karytaina the [[Lousios]] flows into the Alfeios, and the Alfeios continues northwest, passing north of [[Andritsaina]]. Near [[Tripotamia]] the rivers [[Ladon (river)|Ladon]] and [[Erymanthos (river)|Erymanthos]] flow into the Alfeios. The Alfeios then flows west along [[Olympia, Greece|Olympia]] and empties into the [[Ionian Sea]] south of [[Pyrgos, Elis|Pyrgos]].
The ancient highway linking [[Patras]] and [[Kalamata]] ran along this river for most of the length east of Olympia.
In [[Greek mythology]], the [[Pineios River (Peloponnese)|Peneus]] and [[Alpheus (deity)|Alpheus]] were two rivers re-routed by [[Heracles]] in his [[Labours of Hercules|fifth labour]] in order to clean the filth from the [[Augean Stables]] in a single day, a task which had been presumed to be impossible. A poem by [[Roger Caillois]], called ''Le fleuve Alphée'' (the Alpheus River), is mainly about this river.
In the [[Aeneid]], [[Virgil]] describes the ''Alpheus'' as flowing under the sea to resurface at [[Ortygia]] on [[Sicily]], or "so runs the tale".<ref>''Aeneid'', Book III, 694–696</ref>

{{Refimprove|section|date=May 2015}} [[Image:Altarcard.jpg|thumbnail|right|300px|A center altar card, containing the words of Consecration and other prayers]] '''Altar cards''' are three cards placed on the [[altar]] during the [[Tridentine Mass]].<ref name=CE>{{cite Catholic Encyclopedia |wstitle=Altar (in Liturgy) |volume=1 |first=Augustin Joseph |last=Schulte}}</ref> They contain certain prayers that the priest must say during the Mass, and their only purpose is as a memory aid, although they are usually very beautifully decorated.
==History== Altar cards were not used before the sixteenth century, and even today they are not used when a [[bishop]] celebrates the Tridentine Mass, because he reads the entire Mass from the Pontifical Canon.<ref name=CE/> When [[Pope Pius V|Pope St. Pius V]] restored the Missal, only the card at the middle of the altar was used, and it was called the "Tabella Secretarum".<ref name=CE/> The left card was added first, and then the right one was added for the sake of symmetry.<ref name=CE/>
==Content of the cards== The altar card on the left contains the [[Last Gospel]] (John 1:1–14), which is said at the very end of the Mass. The card on the right contains the prayer for blessing the wine and water ("Deus qui humanæ substantiæ") and the ''Lavabo'' ("I shall wash", from the words of [[Psalm]] 26[25 in the Septuagint/Vulgate]:6–12).
The larger, centre card contains the ''[[Gloria in excelsis Deo|Gloria]]'', the prayer ''Munda cor meum'' recited before reading the Gospel, the ''[[Nicene Creed|Credo]]'', the prayer for offering the [[Sacramental bread|Host]] (''Suscipe, Sancte Pater''), the [[Words of Institution|Words of Consecration]], and portions of the [[Canon of the Mass]]. Usually, the card's centre contains a picture of the [[Crucifixion]].
==Uses and regulations of altar cards==
The altar cards may only stand on the altar during Mass. The center one stands against the [[Church tabernacle|Tabernacle]], [[altar cross]] or other support, and the left and right ones stand against either the candlesticks or the [[Altar in the Catholic Church#Ledge|superstructural steps]] (each called a "gradine") of the altar.
After Mass, they must either be removed or placed face downwards under the altar cover.<ref name=CE/> The cards must be removed for the [[Exposition of the Blessed Sacrament]].<ref name=CE/>

{{for|other uses of "Anchorite" and "Anchoress"|Anchorite (disambiguation)}} [[File:Anchorites Skipton.JPG|thumb|Anchorite's cell in [[Skipton]].]] [[File:anchoress of shere.jpg|thumb|[[Christina Carpenter]] was walled in to a cell in [[Shere]], [[Surrey]].<ref name="Thomas2012" />]] [[File:StAnthony.jpg|thumb|185px|[[Anthony the Great]], father of Christian Monasticism and early anchorite.]] [[File:Teodor Axentowicz, Anachoreta.jpg|thumb|250px|"The Anchorite" by [[Teodor Axentowicz]].]]
An '''anchorite''' or '''anchoret''' (female: '''anchoress'''; adj. anchoritic; from {{lang-grc|ἀναχωρητής}}, ''anachōrētḗs'', "one who has retired from the world",<ref>{{OEtymD|anchorite}}</ref><ref>{{LSJ|a)naxwrhth/s|ἀναχωρητής|ref}}.</ref> from the verb {{lang|grc|ἀναχωρέω}}, ''anachōréō'', signifying "to withdraw", "to retire"<ref>{{LSJ|a)naxwre/w|ἀναχωρέω|shortref}}</ref>) is someone who, for religious reasons, withdraws from secular society so as to be able to lead an intensely prayer-oriented, ascetic, or [[Eucharist]]-focused life. Whilst anchorites are frequently considered to be a type of religious [[hermit]],<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/education/beyond/factsheets/makhist/makhist3_prog3c.shtml BBB Radio 4: Making History – Anchorites]</ref> unlike hermits they were required to take a vow of stability of place, opting instead for permanent enclosure in cells often attached to churches. Also unlike hermits, anchorites were subject to a religious rite of consecration that closely resembled the funeral rite, following which they would be considered dead to the world, a type of living [[saint]]. Anchorites had a certain autonomy, as they did not answer to any ecclesiastical authority other than the bishop.<ref name=":0">{{cite book|title = The Broadview Anthology of British Literature|last = LePan|first = Don|publisher = Broadview Press|year = 2011|isbn = |location = |pages = 348}}</ref>
The anchoritic life is one of the earliest forms of [[Christian monasticism]]. In the [[Catholic Church]] today, it is one of the "[[Consecrated life#Other forms of consecrated life|Other Forms of Consecrated Life]]" and governed by the same norms as the consecrated [[hermit|eremitic]] life.<ref name="vatican.va">[http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG1104/__P1Y.HTM The Code of Canon Law 1983, canon 603]</ref> From the [[12th century|12th]] to the [[16th century|16th]] centuries, female anchorites consistently outnumbered their male equivalents, sometimes by as many as four to one (in the [[13th century]]), dropping eventually to two to one (in the [[15th century]]). The sex of a high number of anchorites, however, is not recorded for these periods.<ref name=":1">{{cite book|title = Anchorites, Wombs And Tombs : Intersections Of Gender And Enclosure In The Middle Ages|last = Herbert McAvoy|first = Liz|publisher = University of Wales|year = 2005|isbn = |location = |pages = 13}}</ref>
== Anchoritic life == The anchoritic life became widespread during the early and high [[Middle Ages]].{{sfn|McAvoy|2010|p=96}} Examples of the dwellings of anchorites and anchoresses survive. A large number of these are in England. They tended to be a simple cell (also called '''anchorhold'''), built against one of the walls of the local village church.{{sfn|Licence|2013|p=87–9}} In [[Germanic languages|Germanic-speaking]] areas, from at least the [[10th century]], it was customary for the bishop to say [[The Office of the Dead]] as the anchorite entered his cell, to signify the anchorite's death to the world and rebirth to a spiritual life of solitary communion with God and the angels. Sometimes, if the anchorite were walled up inside the cell, the bishop would put his seal upon the wall to stamp it with his authority. Some anchorites, however, freely moved between their cell and the adjoining church.{{sfn|Licence|2013|p=123, 120}}
Most anchoritic strongholds were small, perhaps no more than {{convert|12|to|15|ft|m|abbr=on|order=flip}} square, with three windows. Viewing the altar, hearing [[Mass (liturgy)|Mass]], and receiving the [[Eucharist]] was possible through one small, shuttered window in the common wall facing the sanctuary, called a "[[hagioscope]]" or "squint". Anchorites would also provide spiritual advice and counsel to visitors through this window, as the anchorites gained a reputation for [[Wisdom#Religious perspectives|wisdom]].{{sfn|Licence|2013|p=158-72}} Another small window would allow access to those who saw to the anchorite's physical needs, such as food and other necessities. A third window, often facing the street, but covered with translucent cloth, would allow light into the cell.<ref name=":0" />
Anchorites were supposed to remain in their cell in all eventualities. Some were even burned in their cells, which they refused to leave even when pirates or other attackers were looting and burning their towns.{{sfn|Licence|2013|p=77-9}} They ate frugal meals, spending their days both in contemplative prayer and interceding on behalf of others. Anchorites' bodily waste was managed by means of a [[chamber pot]].<ref>The Anchoress (2008-06-02). On-line Q&As. Retrieved in 2008-10 from http://theanchoressonline.com/2008/06/02/questions-comments-from-the-email/.</ref>
In addition to being the physical location wherein the anchorite could embark on the journey towards union with God, the anchorhold also provided a spiritual and geographic focus for people from the wider society who came to ask for advice and spiritual guidance. Although set apart from the community at large by stone walls and specific spiritual precepts, the anchorite also lay at the very centre of that same community. The anchorhold has been called a communal 'womb' from which would emerge an idealized sense of a community's own reborn potential, both as Christians and as human subjects.<ref name=":1" />
An idea of their daily routine can be gleaned from an anchoritic Rule. The most widely known today is the early [[13th century]] text known as ''[[Ancrene Wisse]]''.<ref>[[Ancrene Wisse]]</ref> Another, less widely known, example is the rule known as ''De Institutione Inclusarum'' written in the [[12th century]], around 1160–62, by [[Aelred of Rievaulx]] for his sister.<ref>Translated by Mary Paul MacPherson in ''Treatises and the Pastoral Prayer'', Cistercian Fathers Series 2, (Kalamazoo, 1971). In English the work is variously titled ''The Eremitical Life'', ''The Rule of Life for a Recluse'' and ''The Training of Anchoresses''.</ref> It is estimated that the daily set devotions detailed in ''Ancrene Wisse'' would take some four hours, on top of which anchoresses would listen to services in the church, and engage in their own private prayers and devotional reading.<ref>''Ancrene Wisse'', trans Hugh White, (Penguin, 1993), p.viii</ref>
== Famous anchorites == The earliest recorded anchorites lived in the [[3rd century]] CE. For example, [[Hilarion]] ([[Gaza Strip|Gaza]], 291–[[Cyprus]], 371) was known as the founder of anchoritic life in [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]].<ref>''[[Catholic Encyclopedia]]'', [[Jerome|St. Jerome]], Vita Sancti Hilarionis in P. L., III, 29-54.</ref>
The anchoritic life proved especially popular in England. Well-known anchorites include:{{citation needed|date=November 2016}} * [[Bede]] records that, prior to a conference in 602 with [[Augustine of Canterbury]], British churchmen consulted an anchorite about whether to abandon their [[Celtic Christianity|Celtic Christian]] traditions for the Roman practices which Augustine was seeking to introduce.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}} * Towards the end of the [[7th century]], [[Guthlac of Crowland]], related by blood to the [[Mercia|Kingdom of Mercia]], withdrew from the monastery at [[Repton]] to an island in the Lincolnshire Fens, where he lived for some 15–20 years.<ref>''Ancrene Wisse'', trans Hugh White, (Penguin, 1993), p.xiii</ref> * [[Wulfric of Haselbury]] was enclosed as an anchorite in a cell built against the church in his village of Haselbury.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}} * [[Christina Carpenter|Christine Carpenter]], who submitted a petition in 1329<ref>[http://courseweb.stthomas.edu/medieval/julian/petition.htm Petition to Become an Anchoress] University of Saint Thomas–Saint Paul, MN, http://courseweb.stthomas.edu, 2003, 2012-04-22</ref> and was granted permission to become the Anchoress of [[Shere]] Church<ref>[http://sheredelight.com/history.html History of Shere], sheredelight.com, 2011, 2012-04-22</ref> (aka. [[Grade I listed buildings in Surrey#Guildford|The Church of St. James]]), in the [[Borough of Guildford]], England. She received her food and drink from friends and family through a metal grating on the outside wall. In the interior of the church a [[quatrefoil]] shape was cut out of the wall through which she could receive the Eucharist and a [[hagioscope]] for her use for prayer and reflection. She left her cell, and in 1332 she applied again and was granted permission to be re-enclosed.<ref name="Thomas2012">{{cite book|author=Wyndham Thomas|title=Robert Saxton: Caritas|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OtHDa15XkTcC&pg=PA16|year=2012|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-0-7546-6601-1|pages=16–20}}</ref> * [[Margaret Kirkby]] (possibly 1322<ref name="oxforddnb.com">Jonathan Hughes, ‘Kirkby, Margaret (d. 1391x4)’, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004. Retrieved on 2011-05-06 from http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/57764.</ref> to 1391–4), an anchoress at [[Hampole]], Yorkshire for whom [[Richard Rolle]] wrote his [[vernacular]] guide ''The Form of Living''.<ref>Ancrene Wisse, trans Hugh White, (Penguin, 1993), p.xiii</ref> * [[Walter Hilton]] composed the first book of his ''Scale of Perfection'' for an unnamed enclosed woman.<ref>Hilton, W., ''The Scale of Perfection'', tr. J. P. Clark & R. Dorward ([[New York City]]: [[Paulist Fathers|Paulist Press]], 1991), p. 19.</ref> * [[Julian of Norwich]], whose writings have left a lasting impression on Christian spirituality.<ref>[[Revelations of Divine Love]]</ref> Her cell, attached to [[St Julian's Church, Norwich]], was destroyed during an air raid during [[World War II]]. The church itself was gutted but the original walls remain, and it was rebuilt. On the site of the cell is a modern shrine to Julian.<ref>Milton, R., ''Julian's Cell: The Earthy Story of Julian of Norwich'' ([[Kelowna|Kelowna, B.C.]]: Northstone Publishing, 2002).</ref>
The evidence supports the existence of a total of around 780 anchorites on 600 sites in England between 1100 and 1539 during the [[Dissolution of the Monasteries]] ordered by [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]], which brought anchoritism in England to an end. Women were more numerous among the anchorites than men, especially in the [[13th century]].<ref>''Ancrene Wisse'', trans Hugh White, (Penguin, 1993)</ref>
English anchorholds can still be seen at [[Chester-le-Street]] in [[County Durham]] and at [[Hartlip]] in [[Kent]].{{citation needed|date=November 2016}}

{{Bahá'í sidebar}} The '''Bahá'í Faith in Laos''' begins after a brief mention by [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] in 1916{{cite book|author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition = Paperback |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn = 0-87743-233-3 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp-7.html.iso8859-1#gr10 | pages = 40–42 |origyear = 1916-17}} and the first Bahá'í enters Laos in about 1955.{{cite book| last = Effendi | first = Shoghi | authorlink = Shoghi Effendi | title = Messages to the Bahá’í World: 1950–1957 | publisher = US Bahá’í Publishing Trust| edition = 1971 | date = April 1956 | location = Wilmette, USA | page = 92 | url = http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/MBW/mbw-53.html.iso8859-1#gr5 | doi = | id =| isbn =}} The first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] is known to be first elected by 1958{{cite journal | title = Vientiane Assembly Legally Recognized| journal = Bahá'í News |date=August 1960 | issue = 353 | page = 8 | url =}} in [[Vientiane]]{{cite web | url =http://bahai-library.com/handscause_statistics_1953-63&chapter=1#19 | title = The Bahá'í Faith: 1844-1963: Information Statistical and Comparative, Including the Achievements of the Ten Year International Bahá'í Teaching & Consolidation Plan 1953-1963| author = Compiled by [[Hands of the Cause]] Residing in the Holy Land | pages = 25, 50}} and eventually Laos' own National Spiritual Assembly is first elected in 1967.{{cite web| last = Hassall | first = Graham | authorlink = | title = National Spiritual Assemblies Lists and years of formation | work = | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | year = 2000 | url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_nsas_years_formation | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-12-30}} The current community is approximately eight thousand adherents and four centers: [[Vientiane]], [[Vientiane Province]], [[Kaysone Phomvihane (District)|Kaysone Phomvihane]], [[Pakxe]]{{cite web | author = U.S. State Department | title = Laos - International Religious Freedom Report 2006 | publisher = The Office of Electronic Information, Bureau of Public Affair | date = 2006-09-15 | url =https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71346.htm | accessdate = 2008-12-30}} and smaller populations in other provinces.{{cite web| author = U.S. State Department | title = Laos - International Religious Freedom Report 2001 | publisher = The Office of Electronic Information, Bureau of Public Affair | date = 2005-10-26 | url =https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2001/5607.htm | accessdate = 2008-12-30}} While well established and able to function as communities in these cities, Bahá'ís have a harder time in other provinces and cannot print their own religious materials.{{cite web| author = U.S. State Department | title = Laos - International Religious Freedom Report 2005 | publisher = The Office of Electronic Information, Bureau of Public Affair | date = 2005-11-08 | url = https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51517.htm | accessdate = 2008-12-30}} The [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] (relying on [[World Christian Encyclopedia]]) estimated almost 14000 Bahá'ís in 2005.{{cite web| title = Most Baha'i Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions > | publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives | year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp |accessdate = 2009-07-04}} == Early days == === `Abdu'l-Bahá's Tablets of the Divine Plan === Between 1883 and 1954 Laos was part of [[French Indochina]]. `Abdu'l-Bahá, head of the religion from 1892 to 1921, mentions French Indochina. `Abdu'l-Bahá wrote a series of letters, or [[tablets (religious)|tablets]], to the followers of the religion in the [[United States]] in 1916-1917; these letters were compiled together in the book titled [[Tablets of the Divine Plan]]. The seventh of the tablets mentioned taking the Bahá'í Faith to [[Indochina]] and was written on April 11, 1916, but was delayed in being presented in the United States until 1919 — after the end of [[World War I]] and the [[Spanish flu]]. These tablets were translated and presented by [[Mirza Ahmad Sohrab]] on April 4, 1919, and published in [[Star of the West (Bahá'í magazine)|Star of the West]] magazine on December 12, 1919.{{cite book| last = Abbas | first = 'Abdu'l-Bahá |others=Mirza Ahmad Sohrab (trans. and comments) | title = Tablets, Instructions and Words of Explanation |date=April 1919 | url = http://bahai-library.com/abdulbaha_tablets_instructions_explanation}}
(Tablet 7) "The moment this divine Message is carried forward by the American believers from the shores of America and is propagated through the continents of [[Europe]], of [[Asia]], of [[Africa]] and of [[Australasia]], and as far as the islands of the Pacific, this community will find itself securely established upon the throne of an everlasting dominion..., if some teachers go to other islands and other parts, such as the continent of [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]], [[Tasmania]], also to [[Japan]], [[Geography of Russia|Asiatic Russia]], [[Korea]], French Indochina, [[Siam]], [[Straits Settlements]], [[India]], [[Ceylon]] and [[Afghanistan]], most great results will be forthcoming."
=== Beginnings === [[Shoghi Effendi]], head of the religion from 1921 to 1957, claims the first Bahá'ís to arrive in Laos and Cambodia probably in 1955 (came by April, 1956, and after Laotian independence in 1954.) This was Dr. Heshmat Ta'eed, the first pioneer to Laos.{{cite journal | title = Around the World - Laos | journal = Bahá'í News |date=September 1978 | issue = 570 | page = 14 | url =}} The first person to join the Bahá'í Faith in Laos was Bui Van-an who was visiting from Vietnam.{{cite journal | title = Correction | journal = Bahá'í News |date=December 1978 | issue = 573 | page = 21 | url =}} In August 1956 it is noted Bahá'ís from Laos tried to attend the regional conference in Djakarta, Indonesia but were denied visas.{{cite journal | title = Intercontinental Committees - Asia - First couth Asia Teaching Conference held in Djakarta | journal = Bahá'í News |date=October 1956 | issue = 308 | page = 3 | url =}} However, in November seventeen Bahá'ís representing Thailand, Laos, Cambodia, and Vietnam met in Saigon, Vietnam for a regional conference.{{cite journal | title = Seventeen Bahá'ís representing… | journal = Bahá'í News |date=January 1957 | issue = 311 | page = 6 | url =}} In January 1958 the Bahá'ís of Vientiane celebrated [[World Religion Day]] with Buddhist Monks, a Sihk, a Hindu and government officials - and a Miss Banu Hassan is noted as another pioneer in Laos coming from the United States.{{cite journal | title = Four Faiths Join in Observance of World Reliqion Day in Laos | journal = Bahá'í News |date=April 1958 | issue = 326 | page = 11 | url =}} In February the Bahá'ís in Vientiane hosted a regional conference with Bahá'ís from Vietnam and Thailand attending.{{cite journal | title = Confirmations of Spirit Recounted By Pioneer to Buddhist Thailand | journal = Bahá'í News |date=August 1958 | issue = 330 | pages = 21–22 | url =}} In April 1958 the first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] is known to be first elected. By August 1958 there is mention of a native conversion to the religion - a woman member of a black Thai ethnic minority. In December 1958 Bahá'ís from Laos again attended an event in Saigon.{{cite journal | title = First Winter School in Saigon Attracts Baha'is of Five Nations | journal = Bahá'í News |date=March 1958 | issue = 325 | page = 18 | url =}} There is also a very brief mention of a Bahá'í center in [[Vientiane]] circa 1958 where [[Thomas Anthony Dooley III]], aka Dr. Tom Dooley, picked up his Laotian translator, [[Ngoan van Hoang]].{{cite book| last = T. Fisher | first = James | title = Dr. America: The Lives of Thomas A. Dooley, 1927-1961 | publisher = Univ of Massachusetts Pres | year = 1998 | location = Univ of Massachusetts | page = 183 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=rA8cm8l7JXsC&pg=PA183&lpg=PA183 | doi = | id =| isbn = 978-1-55849-154-0}} In January 1959 Vientiane Bahá'ís again held the World Religion Day observance.{{cite journal | title = Newspaper and Radio Publicity, Visual Aids Assist in Proclaiming World Religion Day Observances on Theme of The Oneness of Religion; The audience at the special World Religion Day Program in Vientiane… | journal = Bahá'í News |date=March 1959 | issue = 337 | page = 9 | url =}} By April 1959 the Bahá'ís had elected a Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]]{{cite journal | title = Endowment in Vientiane Purchased | journal = Bahá'í News |date=April 1959 | issue = 338 | page = 2 | url =}} and a registered group of Bahá'ís was living in Sam Neua.{{cite journal | title = Baha'i Group Of Sam Neua, Laos in April 1959| journal = Bahá'í News |date=August 1959 | issue = 342 | page = 15 | url =}} In November 1959 the Bahá'ís in Vientiane hosted a winter school with Bahá'ís from Cambodia, Thailand, and Vietnam attending.{{cite journal | title = The Standards of the New Race | journal = Bahá'í News |date=January 1959 | issue = 335 | pages = 11–13 | url =}} The 1960 observance of World Religion Day gathered about 300 attendees, including members of the King's Council, Consular and United Nations officials, and representatives of various sects of six religions who took part and heard a message from the king of Laos, brought to the meeting by a prince.{{cite book |editor = Rabbani, R. |year = 1992 |title = The Ministry of the Custodians 1957-1963 |publisher = Bahá'í World Centre |isbn = 0-85398-350-X |pages = 187, 221 |url = http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ministry_custodians}}{{cite journal | title = The Oneness of Religion Proclaimed to Millions on World Religion Day| journal = Bahá'í News |date=March 1960 | issue = 349 | pages = 2–4 | url =}} It was also in 1960 that Bahá'ís in Vientiane acquired an authorization confirming through a special decree issued by the Ministry of Finance in Laos for the Bahá'í Community to own in its name a plot of land as an endowment. == Growth == From 1957 to 1963 the regional National Assembly of South East Asia oversaw the Bahá'í communities of area from Borneo to the Philippines to Thailand with a local spiritual assembly in Vientiane. The first Thai pioneer left on June 1, 1960, for Luang Prabang Laos.{{cite journal | title = Baha'is of Bangkok, Thailand, at a farewell…| journal = Bahá'í News |date=August 1960 | issue = 353 | page = 20 | url =}} By December 1960 the first from the ''Maew'' or [[Hmong people]] in Laos accept the religion in Luang Prabang where there is also an assembly.{{cite journal | title = The first believers from the Maew tribe…| journal = Bahá'í News |date=August 1960 | issue = 357 | page = 5 | url =}} It is also known that Jacqueline and Chester Lee, who had become Bahá'ís in Cambodia in 1955, moved to Vietienne 1965 where they lived until they moved to Hong Kong (Chester left in 1967 while Jacqueline left in 1969.){{cite web| last = Hassall | first = Graham | title = Bahá'íFaith in Hong Kong | work = approved for publication by the Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Hong Kong | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | date = January 2000 | url =http://bahai-library.com/hassall_bahai_hong_kong | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-12-30}} In Oct 1963, the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Thailand, with its seat in [[Bangkok]], was given jurisdiction over the Bahá'ís of Laos{{cite book| last = Universal House of Justice | first = | authorlink = Universal House of Justice | title = Wellspring of Guidance; Messages of the Universal House of Justice 1963-68 | publisher = United States Baha'i Publishing Trust | year = 1969 | location = Wilmette, IL | page = 17 | url = http://bahai-library.com/uhj_wellspring_guidance | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-87743-032-2}} until 1967 when they elected their own National Spiritual Assembly with the presence of the first [[Hand of the Cause]] to visit Laos - Dr. [[Rahmatu'lláh Muhájir]].{{cite journal | title = News from the World Center; | journal = Bahá'í News |date=August 1960 | issue = 431 | page = 1 | url =}} The members of the first national assembly were: F. Missaghian, Sy Chanh, Boon My, M. Beizayee, F. Antipolo, L. Kham Say, Lau Chou, F. Faridian and C. M. Lee.{{cite journal | title = Laos Elects First National SpirituaI Assembly in Vientiane| journal = Bahá'í News |date=July 1967 | issue = 436 | page = 10 | url =}} In October 1967 an intercontinental conference was held in New Delhi with several Hands of the Cause and representatives of National Spiritual Assemblies from India, Ceylon, Arabia, Laos, Thailand, North East Africa, Philippines, Iran, Indonesia, Korea, Taiwan, Malaysia, South and Central Arabia, Turkey and Pakistan present.{{cite journal | title = Events Spark First Baha'i Press Conference in India; Four Hands of the Cause Present| journal = Bahá'í News |date=December 1967 | issue = 441 | page = 32 | url =}} About February 1969 Hand of the Cause [[Abu'l-Qásim Faizi]], the second to visit Laos, met with the national assembly.{{cite journal | title = Hands of the Cause of God Travel Throughout World| journal = Bahá'í News |date=March 1969 | issue = 456 | page = 2 | url =}} In April 1969 Dr. Rahmatu'lláh Muhájir made a return trip to Laos.{{cite journal | title = Intercontinental Travels Of The Hands Of The Cause Of God| journal = Bahá'í News |date=August 1969 | issue = 461 | page = 3 | url =}} At the fourth national convention, April 1970, it announced that the first members of the [[Puthai]], a tribe in the [[Savannakhet]] area, as well as [[Meo]] in Laos, had joined the religion.{{cite journal | title = Intercontinental Travels Of The Hands Of The Cause Of God| journal = Bahá'í News |date=August 1970 | issue = 473 | page = 17 | url =}} By September 1970 the Laotian Bahá'í Publishing Trust had translated four Baha'i English books, pamphlets, and a prayer book into the [[Lao language]]{{cite journal | title = Laos | journal = Bahá'í News |date=September 1970 | issue = 474 | page = 12 | url =}} and local conferences in Savannakhet and Thakkek were called with Bahá'ís from each region attending.{{cite journal | title = Progress In Laos | journal = Bahá'í News |date=March 1971 | issue = 480 | page = 19 | url =}} In January 1971 native Laotian Bahá'ís were able to travel to an international Bahá'í conference in Singapore.{{cite journal | title = War Torn Laos | journal = Bahá'í News |date=May 1971 | issue = 482 | page = 16 | url =}} In February Hand of the Cause [[Enoch Olinga]] visited Laos{{cite journal | title = Vietnam Visited by Hand of the Cause Enoch Olinga | journal = Bahá'í News |date=April 1971 | issue = 481 | page = 19 | url =}} and in October Hand of the Cause [[Collis Featherstone]] visited Laos and traveled to several regions of Laos as well as meeting with the national assembly.{{cite journal | title = News from Laos | journal = Bahá'í News |date=March 1972 | issue = 492 | page = 16 | url =}} In 1972 several trips of Bahá'ís spread word that [[Maitreya]] Buddha had returned as [[Bahá'u'lláh]] - during which time the population of Bahá'ís greatly expanded.{{cite journal | title = Bahá'u'lláh Proclaimed as Fifth Buddha In Laos | journal = Bahá'í News |date=November 1972 | issue = 499 | page = 21 | url =}} In accord with a government request, land owned by the assembly of Vientiane was converted for growing crops - a team of youth cleared the land, fenced it in, planted and managed the crops.{{cite journal | title = Around the World - Laos; Crops are planted at Baha'i properties| journal = Bahá'í News |date=March 1976 | issue = 540 | pages = 22–23 | url =}} The second youth training institute was late January 1976 and included sessions included workshops on Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly|Local Spiritual Assemblies]], Bahá'í views on [[Bahá'í marriage|marriage]], [[Bahá'í history|history of the religion]], [[Nineteen Day Feast|Feasts]] and [[Bahá'í Holy Days#Holy days|Bahá'í Holy Days]], the Bahá'í [[Nineteen Day Fast]] among other topics.{{cite journal | title = Around the World - Laos; Youth participate in training institute| journal = Bahá'í News |date=April 1976 | issue = 541 | pages = 17–18 | url =}} In May 1978 the national center in Vientiane hosted the first national children's convention.{{cite journal | title = Around the World - Laos| journal = Bahá'í News |date=December 1978 | issue = 573 | page = 17 | url =}} == Modern community == {{Location map many | Laos | width= 260 | float=right |border= blue|caption = some cities in Laos with Bahá'ís | label= Vientiane |lat_deg=17 |lat_min=58 |lat_dir=N | |lon_deg=102 |lon_min=36 |lon_dir=E | label2= Pakxe |lat2_deg=15 | lat2_min=07| lon2_deg =105 | lon2_min =47 | | label3= Kaysone Phomvihane | lat3_deg =16 | lat3_min =33| lon3_deg =104 | lon3_min =45 | label4= Luang Prabang | lat4_deg = 19 | lat4_min = 53 | lon4_deg = 102 | lon4_min = 8 }} === Focus on the society at large === Since its inception the religion has had involvement in [[socio-economic development]] beginning by giving greater freedom to women,{{cite web | last = Momen | first = Moojan | title = History of the Baha'i Faith in Iran | work = draft "A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith" | publisher = Bahai-library.com | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_iran#9.%20Social%20and%20economic%20development | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-10-16}} promulgating the promotion of female education as a priority concern,{{cite journal | last = Kingdon | first = Geeta Gandhi | title = Education of women and socio-economic development | journal = Baha'i Studies Review | volume = 7 | issue = 1 | year = 1997 | url =http://bahai-library.com/kingdon_education_women_development }} and that involvement was given practical expression by creating schools, agricultural coops, and clinics. The religion entered a new phase of activity when a message of the [[Universal House of Justice]] dated 20 October 1983 was released.{{cite journal |title= The Baha'i Faith 1957–1988: A Survey of Contemporary Developments | first = Moojan | last = Momen |author2=Smith, Peter | year = 1989 | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_smith_developments_1957-1988 |volume = 19 | journal = Religion |issue= 1 | pages=63–91 |doi= 10.1016/0048-721X(89)90077-8}} Bahá'ís were urged to seek out ways, compatible with the [[Bahá'í teachings]], in which they could become involved in the social and economic development of the communities in which they lived. Worldwide in 1979 there were 129 officially recognized Bahá'í socio-economic development projects. By 1987, the number of officially recognized development projects had increased to 1482. In 1983 30 teachers of children's classes gathered for a seminar that included topics like the [[List of Bahá'ís#Central figures|Central Figures]] of the Bahá'í Faith, [[Baha'i administration]], [[Bahá'í teachings]] on loyalty to government and abstention from politics, and a viewing of Hand of the Cause [[Rúhíyyih Khanum]]'s trip turned into the movie ''The Green Light Expedition''.{{cite journal| title = The World; Laos| journal = Bahá'í News |date=March 1984 | issue = 636 |issn=0195-9212 | page = 16 | url =}} In 1983 scores of children regularly attend classes at [[Bahá'í school]]s held at the Ban Amon Bahá'í Center at the national center in Vientiane.{{cite journal| title = The World; Laos| journal = Bahá'í News |date=April 1984 | issue = 637 |issn=0195-9212 | page = 16 | url =}} By February 1984 other projects Bahá'ís undertook include an assembly purchasing two cows and a community garden with profits from sales going to national and local funds.{{cite journal| title = Social/economic development - Part II of our world-wide survey; (section on Laos)| journal = Bahá'í News |date=April 1986 | issue = 637 |issn=0195-9212 | page = 10 | url =}} In the 1980s, among the many refugees who came to the United States following the [[Vietnam War]], were 200 [[Hmong people|Hmong]] Bahá'ís from Laos who settled in Portland, Oregon.{{cite web|last= |first= |authorlink= |title=Portland Bahá'í History |work=Official Website of the Portland Metro Bahai Faith Communities |publisher=Portland Metro Bahai Faith Communities |year=2008 |url=http://portlandmetro.bahai.us/portland-bahai-history |format= |doi= |accessdate=2008-12-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081105154325/http://portlandmetro.bahai.us/portland-bahai-history |archivedate=2008-11-05 |df= }} The Bahá'í community of Portland set up an after-school tutoring project initially aiming at war-torn Liberia but lacking practical connection turned to serve the Hmong children in the area around 2000-2001 and has since become more organized into a project - the Roses After School Mentoring Project.{{Cite news|last=Venema |first=Sheri |title=Preserving presence The Hmong try to maintain their culture through the younger generation |newspaper=The Oregonian |pages= |date=2003-07-26 |url=http://www.bahaindex.com/en/news/1-general-news/2736-preserving-presence-the-hmong-try-to-maintain-their-culture-through-the-younger-generation |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100223011426/http://www.bahaindex.com/en/news/1-general-news/2736-preserving-presence-the-hmong-try-to-maintain-their-culture-through-the-younger-generation |archivedate=2010-02-23 |df= }} === Focus on internal development === [[File:Laos Baha'i gathering 2009.jpg|thumb|right|A Baha'i gathering in [[Vientiane]] in 2009.]] In 1983 there were nineteen delegates for the national convention.{{cite journal | title = National Conventions - Cause gains momentum on many fronts; Laos| journal = Bahá'í News |date=October 1983 | issue = 631 |issn=0195-9212 | pages = 2–3 | url =}} In 1988 Hand of the Cause Collis Featherstone again toured Laos including giving public talks as well as visiting refugee camps.{{cite journal | title = The World - Thailand| journal = Bahá'í News |date=February 1989 | issue = 695 |issn=0195-9212 | page = 15 | url =}} However the community in Laos has been frustrated. After experiencing quick growth in the early 1970s (see above), in the 1980s the community had reached approximately eight thousand adherents and four centers: two in [[Vientiane]], one in [[Vientiane Province]], in the northwest and one in [[Kaysone Phomvihane (District)|Kaysone Phomvihane]], Savannakhet Province mid-south with smaller numbers of Bahá'ís just north of Savannakhet in [[Khammouane Province]] and in the city of [[Pakxe]] in the far south and smaller populations in other provinces. The land on which the four Bahá'í centers were located was approved by the Lao government for use by the Bahá'ís. Additionally, the government has given official approval for Bahá'ís to use land where they already have a cemetery. The Bahá'ís were planning to construct new spiritual centers in Savannkhet's Dong Bang Village and in Lat Khouay Village near Vientiane. They have received both village and district level approval to use the land, but were awaiting the official land deeds from the District Land Offices. The Bahá'í spiritual assemblies in Vientiane and Kaysone Phomvihane cities practiced freely, but smaller communities in Khammouane and Savannakhet provinces have periodically faced restrictions by local authorities. From 2001 some local officials in [[Luang Prabang]] in the north central area acted harshly toward Bahá'ís and Christians. Examples included forced renunciations that sometimes involved forced participation in animist traditions, including the drinking of animal blood. Other officials forced some believers to drink alcohol and smoke cigarettes against their will. Efforts by local officials to force Bahá'ís to renounce their faith continued in some areas. In more isolated cases, provincial authorities instructed their officials to monitor and arrest Bahá'ís and other religions. In some cases in 2005 some Bahá'ís were threatened with arrest or expulsion from their villages in some provinces if they did not comply The Vientiane Bahá'í assembly previously encountered difficulties establishing its ownership of the Bahá'í center in Vientiane; however, in 2005 authorities granted approval for use of the property by the Bahá'ís. Bahá'í local spiritual assemblies and the national spiritual assembly routinely held Bahá'í [[Nineteen Day Feast]]s and celebrated all [[Bahá'í calendar#Holy days|Bahá'í holy days]]. The National Spiritual Assembly based in Vientiane met regularly and has sent delegations to the [[Universal House of Justice]] in [[Haifa]], Israel. The Government prohibited foreigners from proselytizing, although it permitted foreign non-governmental organizations (NGOs) with religious affiliations to work in the country. Foreigners caught distributing religious materials could be arrested or deported. Decree 92 specifically authorized proselytizing by local citizens, providing the Lao Front for National Construction (LFNC) (see [[Constitution of Laos]]) approves the activity. In practice the authorities interpreted proselytizing as an illegal activity that creates divisiveness in society. Although Decree 92 authorized the printing of non-Buddhist religious texts and allowed religious materials to be imported from abroad, it also required permission for such activities from the LFNC. As early as 2005 there are reports the LFNC did not authorize Bahá'ís to print their own religious materials, although they had been seeking permission to do so for several years. Some believers bring religious materials into the country; however, these persons face possible arrest. As of 2009 outreach is underway in [[Oudomsai]], [[Xiang Khouang]], [[Luang Prabang]], and [[Salavan Province|Salavan]] Provinces.{{cite web | author = U.S. State Department | title = Laos - International Religious Freedom Report 2009 | publisher = The Office of Electronic Information, Bureau of Public Affair | date = 2009-10-26 | url = https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2009/127276.htm | accessdate = 2009-12-29}} === Demographics === There is a 2000 estimate of more than 1,200 members{{cite book| last = Larkin | first = Barbara | authorlink = Barbara Larkin | title = International Religious Freedom (2000): Report to Congress by the Department of State | publisher = DIANE Publishing | year = 2001 | location = Washington D.C., USA | page = 200 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=OTx1qbA8OW8C&pg=PA200&lpg=PA200 | doi = | id =| isbn = 978-0-7567-1229-7 }} and a 2006 estimate of approximately eight thousand. In 2008 Bahá'ís estimated their population at 8,500 adherents.{{cite web | author = U.S. State Department | title = Laos - International Religious Freedom Report 2008 | publisher = The Office of Electronic Information, Bureau of Public Affair | date = 2008-09-19 | url =https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2008/108412.htm | accessdate = 2008-12-30}} The [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] (relying on [[World Christian Encyclopedia]]) estimated some 13,960 Bahá'ís in 2005. == See also == * [[Bahá'í Faith by country]] * [[Religion in Laos]] *: [[Freedom of religion in Laos]] * [[History of Laos]] *: [[Provinces of Laos]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{Asia topic|Bahá'í Faith in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baha'i Faith in Laos}} [[Category:Religion in Laos]] [[Category:Bahá'í Faith by country|Laos]]

{{Unreferenced|date=July 2007}} '''Beglopopovtsy''' ({{lang-rus|Беглопоповцы|p=bʲɪɡləpɐˈpoft͡sɨ}}, "runaway [[priest]]s") was one of the denominations among the [[Popovtsy]], who belonged to the [[Old Believers]].
Since none of the bishops joined the Old Believers movement after the [[Raskol|schism of 1666-67]] in the [[Russian Orthodox Church]], except bishop [[Paul of Kolomna]], who was executed, ordained priests of the old rite would have soon become extinct. Two responses appeared to this dilemma: the “priestist” Old Believers (поповцы ([[Popovtsy]])) and the non-priestist Old Believers (беспоповцы ([[Bespopovtsy]])).
The Beglopopovtsy movement formed in the late 17th century and included priests, who had "deserted" the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] (hence, the name "beglopopovtsy", meaning "with deserted priests"). They settled in the [[Nizhny Novgorod]] region beyond the [[Volga River]] (along the [[Kerzhenets River|Kerzhenets]] and [[Belbash River]]s), around [[Starodub]], [[Chernigov]] (modern ''Chernihiv'', [[Ukraine]]), and on the [[Vetka Island]] (''see [[Vetkovskoye soglasie]]''). In the second half of the 18th century, the Beglopopovtsy formed a group at the [[Rogozhskoye cemetery]] in [[Moscow]].
At the beginning, all priestist Old Believers were beglopopovtsy. They represented the more moderate conservative opposition, who strove to continue religious and church life as it had existed before the reforms of Nikon. They recognized ordained priests from the new style Russian Orthodox church who joined the Old Believers and who had denounced the Nikonian reforms. In 1846 the priestist Old Believers convinced Amvrosii (Popovich, 1791-1863) deposed [[Greek Orthodox]] bishop (who had been removed under Turkish pressure) to become an Old Believer and to consecrate three Russian Old Believers priests as bishops. In 1859, the number of Old Believer bishops in Russia reached ten, and they established their own episcopate, the so-called [[Belokrinitskaya hierarchy]].
Not all priestist Old Believers recognized this new established hierarchy, which provoked a schism within the priestist Old Believers. For various reasons many could not accept this so-called [[Belokrinitskaya Hierarchy]]. From this time priestist Old Believers became divided into two groups: those who accepted the Belokrinitskaya Hierarchy and those who did not. These dissenters were called '''beglopopovtsy''' and obtained their own hierarchy only in the 1920s, the so-called [[Novozybkovskaya Hierarchy]] or [[Russian Old-Orthodox Church]]. From that moment the denomination '''beglopopovtsy''' no longer existed and the term became rarely used.

{{about|the term "Chaplain General" within the Anglican Church|information about the use of this term in numerous militaries around the world|Military chaplain#Chief of chaplains/chaplain general}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2008}} The '''chaplain general''' is a senior chaplain in non-church organisations, such as the British and Canadian armies, and is responsible for the supervision of chaplains conducting religious services and ceremonies, representing the Christian faith in that organisation, and providing pastoral care and support within the organisation.
==History== The post of Chaplain-General in the British Army dates from 1796.<ref name=Roper1998>{{cite book |last1=Roper |first1=Michael |title=The Records of the War Office and Related Departments, 1660-1964 |date=1998 |publisher=Public Record Office |location=Kew, Surrey }}</ref>
During the [[First World War]], the chaplain-general [[John Taylor Smith]] was equivalent to a [[major general]] and under the control of the Permanent Under-Secretary of State. [[Llewellyn Henry Gwynne]] was from July 1915 deputy chaplain-general of the army in France, with the relative rank of major-general. Both had been colonial bishops prior to appointment.
In the [[Second World War]], the head of chaplaincy in the [[British Army]] was an ([[Anglican]]) chaplain-general, who was formally under the control of the Permanent Under-Secretary of State.<ref>C. D. Symons, Chaplain-General to the Forces, 1939-44</ref> An Assistant Chaplain-General was a Chaplain 1st class (full [[Colonel]]) and a senior Chaplain was a Chaplain 2nd class ([[Lieutenant Colonel]]).<ref>Brumwell, P. Middleton (1943) ''The Army Chaplain: the Royal Army Chaplains' Department; the duties of chaplains and morale''. London: Adam & Charles Black</ref>
In 1948 the first [[Bishop to the Forces]] was appointed; the Bishop is a suffragan of the [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], the full title of the Bishop to the Forces is "The Archbishop of Canterbury's Episcopal Representative to the Armed Forces". The Bishop to the Forces is not a [[military chaplain]].<ref name=crockfords100th>''[[Crockford's Clerical Directory]] 2008/2009 (100th ed.)'', London: Church House Publishing {{ISBN|978-0-7151-1030-0}}</ref> The current holder of the office is [[Nigel Stock (bishop)|Nigel Stock]], [[Bishop at Lambeth]]. There is sometimes confusion between the (Anglican) "Bishop ''to'' the Forces" and the (Roman Catholic) [[Bishopric of the Forces|"Bishop ''of'' the Forces"]]: for this reason the latter is normally given his title in full, i.e. "The Roman Catholic Bishop of the Forces".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.catholicchurch.org.uk/Catholic-Church/The-Church-in-England-and-Wales/bishopric_of_the_forces |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100723200543/http://www.catholicchurch.org.uk/Catholic-Church/The-Church-in-England-and-Wales/bishopric_of_the_forces |archivedate=23 July 2010 |df=dmy }}. ''The Catholic Church in England and Wales: the Bishopric of the Forces''. Retrieved on 9 September 2010.</ref>
Each of the three armed services has a chief chaplain (ranking as an archdeacon), for the navy the [[Chaplain of the Fleet]], for the army the Chaplain-General, and for the Royal Air Force the [[Chaplain-in-Chief]].<ref>''Whitaker's Almanack''; 1972; 1988. London: J. Whitaker & Sons; pp. 459; (1988) 464</ref>
The [[Museum of Army Chaplaincy]] holds archive material and information relating to the history of the Chaplains General to the British Army both past and present.
==Outside Anglicanism== [[Military Chaplain#Annual International Chiefs of Chaplains Conference|''Chaplain General'']] is also used as a term outside the Anglican Church, referring to the senior chaplain in a nation's military (sometimes called the ''Chief of Chaplains'', [[Chiefs of Chaplains of the United States|as in the United States military]]). Some nations, like [[South Africa]], [[Israel]], and [[Canada]], have one Chaplain General or Chief of Chaplains for the military as a whole; others, like the [[United States]], have one for each branch of the armed forces; while others have one for each major religion or faith group represented among its military personnel.
==See also== *[[Royal Army Chaplains' Department]] (RAChD) (U.K.) *[[Royal Canadian Chaplain Service]] *[[Chiefs of Chaplains of the United States]] *[[International Military Chiefs of Chaplains Conference]] *[[Military chaplain#Military chaplains by country]]
