{{for|the Irish soldier born in 1920|Christopher O'Dowd}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Chris O'Dowd | image = Chris O'Dowd at British Comedy Awards.jpg | caption = O'Dowd at the [[British Comedy Awards]], December 2013 | birth_name = Christopher O'Dowd | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1979|10|09}} | birth_place = [[Boyle, County Roscommon|Boyle]], [[County Roscommon]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] |alma_mater= [[London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art]] | occupation = Actor | yearsactive = 2003–present | spouse = {{marriage|[[Dawn O'Porter|Dawn Porter]]|2012}} | children = 2 }} '''Christopher O'Dowd''' (born 9 October 1979){{cite web|title=Chris O'Dowd|url=http://www.tv.com/people/chris-odowd/|publisher=[[TV.com]]|accessdate=9 May 2014}}{{cite web|title=Chris O'Dowd biography and filmography|url=http://www.tribute.ca/people/chris-odowd/37331/|work=[[Tribute (magazine)|Tribute]]|accessdate=9 May 2014}} is an Irish actor, best known for his television roles such as [[Get Shorty#Main cast|Miles Daly]] in the [[Epix]] comedy series ''[[Get Shorty (TV series)|Get Shorty]]'' and [[The IT Crowd#Cast and characters|Roy Trenneman]] in the [[Channel 4]] comedy ''[[The IT Crowd]]''. O'Dowd created and starred in the [[Sky 1]] television series ''[[Moone Boy]]'', which aired between 2012 and 2015, earning O'Dowd [[Irish Film and Television Award]] nominations in acting, writing and directing. He had a recurring role on the comedy-drama series ''[[Girls (TV series)|Girls]]''. O'Dowd is also known for his film roles, including ''[[Bridesmaids (2011 film)|Bridesmaids]]'' (2011), ''[[This Is 40]]'' (2012), ''[[The Sapphires (film)|The Sapphires]]'' (2012), ''[[Thor: The Dark World]]'' (2013), ''[[Calvary (2014 film)|Calvary]]'' (2014), and ''[[St. Vincent (film)|St. Vincent]]'' (2014). He made his [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] debut in the play adaptation of ''[[Of Mice and Men]]'' in 2014, for which he was nominated for a [[Tony Award]]. ==Early life== O'Dowd was born and raised in [[Boyle, County Roscommon]]. His father, Seán, is a sign designer, and his mother, Denise, is a counsellor and psychotherapist.{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/esmagazine/chris-odowd-from-cult-it-geek-to-hollywood-antihero-6412084.html|title=Chris O'Dowd: From cult IT geek to Hollywood antihero|author=Laura Barton|date=16 June 2011|work=[[London Evening Standard]]}}{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/starsandstories/8579986/Chris-ODowd-Interview.html|title=Chris O'Dowd Interview|author=Stuart Husband|date=20 June 2011|accessdate=19 October 2012|work=The Daily Telegraph|location=London}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sligochampion.ie/news/boyle-boyle-actor-in-television-debut-938291.html|title=Boyle: Boyle actor in television debut|date=8 January 2003|publisher=[[The Sligo Champion]]}} He is the youngest of five siblings.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2012/may/18/chris-odowd-it-crowd-bridesmaids|title=Chris O'Dowd: from The IT Crowd to Hollywood|author=Hadley Freeman|date=|work=The Guardian|location=London|accessdate=4 December 2015}} He represented Roscommon in [[Gaelic football]] at the under-16, minor and under-21 levels, the highlight being his performance as a goalkeeper in the 1997 Connacht Minor final against Mayo, in a game covered by [[RTÉ Sport]] for highlights on its ''[[The Sunday Game]]'' programme.{{cite web|url=http://www.farmersjournal.ie/site/farming-Roscommon%E2%80%99s-IT-guy-9440.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130412223342/http://www.farmersjournal.ie/site/farming-Roscommon%E2%80%99s-IT-guy-9440.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=12 April 2013 |title=Farm - Farming - Roscommon’s IT guy |publisher=Farmersjournal.ie |accessdate=4 October 2013 }} He studied politics and sociology at [[University College Dublin]], and subsequently attended the [[London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art]]. O'Dowd did not obtain a degree from UCD, telling the UCD student newspaper the ''College Tribune'': "I didn't finish my degree. The politics part of it was fine, but I was doing sociology as well and I could never bring myself to find an interest in it."{{cite web|url=http://collegetribune.ie/chris-o-dowd-talks-to-donie-o-sullivan|title= Standing out from the Crowd|author=Donie O'Sullivan|date=4 April 2012|publisher=[[College Tribune]]|accessdate=19 October 2012}} He contributed to ''[[The University Observer]]'', [[Ógra Fianna Fáil]] and was active in UCD Dramsoc and the [[Literary and Historical Society (University College Dublin)|Literary and Historical Society]]. O'Dowd was an avid member of [[Ógra Fianna Fáil]] and engaged in promotional canvassing for the party amongst UCD's student populace, it was during this time he coined the slogan 'Vote Young Fianna Fáil, for [[hurling]] in the halls'. The slogan was a huge success due to O'Dowd's improvisation with classmate Ronan Kirby's hurley. O'Dowd said in ''The College Tribune'' that he was personally thanked by [[Éamon de Valera]]'s ghost in a dream. ==Career== [[File:Chris O'Dowd.jpg|thumb|O'Dowd at Lingerie London in 2012]] O'Dowd starred in the [[United Kingdom]] in [[Channel 4]]'s comedy ''[[The IT Crowd]]'', [[BBC Two]]'s ''[[Roman's Empire]]'', ''[[Red Cap (TV series)|Red Cap]]'' and the award-winning documentary-drama ''The Year London Blew Up''. He has also appeared on Irish television, having starred in the [[RTÉ One]] drama ''[[The Clinic (TV series)|The Clinic]]'' and the drama ''Showbands'' alongside [[Kerry Katona]]. O'Dowd has appeared in ''[[How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (film)|How to Lose Friends & Alienate People]]'' in a minor role. O'Dowd has also had roles in a number of films, including the 2005 film ''[[Festival (2005 film)|Festival]]'' where he played stand-up comedian Tommy O'Dwyer, a role for which he won a Scottish [[BAFTA]] award, and a small role in ''[[Vera Drake]]''. O'Dowd appears in ''[[Frequently Asked Questions About Time Travel]]'', a comedy sci-fiction film with [[Marc Wootton]], [[Dean Lennox Kelly]] and [[Anna Faris]]. He played Liam in the 2007 German film ''Hotel Very Welcome''. He starred in the 2009 film ''[[The Boat That Rocked]]'', released in Canada and the U.S. as ''Pirate Radio''. The film was inspired by the story of offshore pirate broadcasters [[Radio Caroline]]. O'Dowd plays Simon, the station's breakfast DJ."The breakfast jock on Radio Caroline at the time was Tony Blackburn, so there's definitely an element of him in it,"{{cite web|url=http://suicidegirls.com/interviews/Chris+O'Dowd%3A+The+IT+Man+From+The+IT+Crowd|title=Chris O'Dowd: The IT Man From The IT Crowd|author=Nicole Powers|date=9 May 2009|publisher=[[SuicideGirls]]|accessdate=19 October 2012}} says O'Dowd of his character. "And then I called in different Irish DJs that would have been contemporaries of Tony Blackburn at the time, a guy called [[Larry Gogan]] and a couple of other people." O'Dowd starred opposite [[Sienna Miller]] in the film ''[[Hippie Hippie Shake]]'', which is about the groundbreaking '60s magazine, ''[[Oz (magazine)|Oz]]''. The publication was the precursor to a whole generation of [[lad mags]]. O'Dowd plays [[Felix Dennis]], who would later become the publisher of ''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]''. The story centres on the landmark indecency trial. In preparation for the role, O'Dowd met with Dennis, stating "He was an incredibly charismatic man." In April 2009 it was announced that O'Dowd had been cast in [[Gulliver's Travels (2010 film)|a remake]] of ''[[Gulliver's Travels]]'' as General Edward. "It's shooting in [[Pinewood Studios|Pinewood]] from the end of April", he said, shortly after his participation was announced. "I'm just going back to England to learn how to ride a horse... I'm a general in the army, so there's going to be a little bit of horse riding. I think it's going to be really fun though, we're all kind of learning together." O'Dowd appeared in the 2010 film ''[[Dinner for Schmucks]]'', an American version of the French farce, ''[[Le Dîner de Cons (film)|Le Dîner de Cons]]''.{{cite web|url=http://tv.sky.com/it-crowd-chris-odowd |title=Chris O'Dowd Interview |publisher=[[Sky (UK and Ireland)|Sky TV]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101218030646/http://tv.sky.com/it-crowd-chris-odowd |archivedate=18 December 2010 |df= }} He also appeared on panel show ''[[Never Mind the Buzzcocks]]'' (Season 21, episode 11), and starred in an [[ITV2]] comedy series entitled ''[[FM (2009 TV series)|FM]]''. In 2010, he took part in ''[[Little Crackers]]'', writing and directing a short film loosely based on his own childhood and Christmas in his family home from 1984–88. In April 2011, he starred in the [[BBC]] adaptation of ''[[The Crimson Petal and the White (miniseries)|The Crimson Petal and the White]]'' as William Rackham and appeared in the May 2011 release ''[[Bridesmaids (2011 film)|Bridesmaids]]'' as Officer Nathan Rhodes. O'Dowd had a supporting role in ''[[This Is 40]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/ten/2011/0608/odowdc.html|title=Chris O'Dowd for Knocked Up sequel |publisher=[[RTÉ.ie#Entertainment|RTÉ Ten]]|date=8 June 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/filmandtv/news/it-crowd-star-to-join-knocked-up-spin-off/217939|title='IT Crowd' star to join 'Knocked Up' spin-off|date=8 June 2011|publisher=[[NME]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/film-tv/news/odowd-joins-knocked-up-spinoff-16009393.html|title=O'Dowd joins Knocked Up spin-off|date= 8 June 2011|work=[[The Belfast Telegraph]]}} He described "fighting over [[Megan Fox]] in a pool" during filming as "one of the most fun things I've ever done".{{cn|date=December 2018}} O'Dowd played Dave in Wayne Blair's 2012 debut feature Australian musical ''[[The Sapphires (film)|The Sapphires]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.iftn.ie/news/?act1=record&only=1&aid=73&rid=4284165&tpl=archnews&force=1|title=Chris O'Dowd Joins Aussie Musical 'The Sapphires'|date=16 August 2011|publisher=[[Irish Film and Television Network|IFTN]]}} Based on a popular stage show, it was shot across Australia and Vietnam and produced by [[Goalpost Pictures|Goalpost Australia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/movies/on-location-and-finally-acting-the-part-20111007-1ldhi.html |title=On location and finally acting the part |date=8 October 2011 |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/ten/2011/0816/odowdc.html|title=O'Dowd heads to Vietnam for new movie |date=16 August 2011 |publisher=[[RTÉ.ie#Entertainment|RTÉ Ten]]}} He is to write and [[Executive producer|executive produce]] a new American comedy series called ''Big Men'',{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/ten/2011/1027/odowdc.html|title=O'Dowd set for US comedy series|date=27 October 2011|publisher=[[RTÉ.ie#Entertainment|RTÉ Ten]]}} after NBC won the bidding war for it.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/26/idUS133616300020111026|title=NBC Wins Bidding War for Chris O'Dowd Comedy 'Big Men'|author=Daniel Frankel|date=26 October 2011|publisher=Reuters}} He co-wrote a series based on his childhood called ''[[Moone Boy]]'' for [[Sky 1]].{{cite web|url=http://www.herald.ie/entertainment/around-town/odowd-hunts-twins-for-his-new-tv-series-2946656.html|title=O'Dowd hunts twins for his new TV series|author=Caroline Crawford|date=26 November 2011|work=[[Evening Herald]]}} Segments of the series, which ran from 2012 to 2015, were filmed in his hometown, [[Boyle, County Roscommon|Boyle]]. A book based on the series and also co-written by O'Dowd, ''Moone Boy: The Blunder Years'', was published in May 2015. Subsequent release include "Moone Boy: The Fish Detective", published in October 2015, "Moone Boy: The Notion Potion", published in September 2017, as well as an activity book, "Moone Boy: The Marvellous Activity Manual", published in May 2017. From April to July, 2014, O'Dowd starred in the Broadway revival of ''[[Of Mice and Men (play)|Of Mice and Men]]'', directed by [[Anna D. Shapiro]] and co-starring [[James Franco]] and [[Leighton Meester]].[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/184854-James-Franco-and-Chris-ODowd-Will-Make-Broadway-Debuts-in-Revival-of-Of-Mice-and-Men ''Of Mice and Men''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223062846/http://playbill.com/news/article/184854-James-Franco-and-Chris-ODowd-Will-Make-Broadway-Debuts-in-Revival-of-Of-Mice-and-Men |date=23 February 2014 }}, playbill.com; accessed 25 April 2014. For this, he was nominated for a [[Drama Desk Award|Drama Desk]] and [[Tony Award for Best Actor in a Play]]. He starred as a Catholic school teacher in the 2014 film ''[[St. Vincent (film)|St. Vincent]]'' with Bill Murray and Melissa McCarthy. O'Dowd was the narrator for the 2014 RTÉ documentary ''Man on Bridge''. ==Personal life== O'Dowd married Scottish writer, director, and television presenter [[Dawn O'Porter|Dawn Porter]] in 2012. After their marriage, Dawn changed her surname to O'Porter.{{cite news| url=http://www.evoke.ie/showbiz/chris-o-dowd-baby-due-date-revealed-january-dawn-o-porter/|work=evoke.ie | title= January baby! Chris O'Dowd's father reveals his baby with Dawn O'Porter is due early next year| date=22 October 2014}} Despite being raised in a [[Roman Catholic]] family, O'Dowd has been a lifelong [[atheist]], and has developed an [[antitheist]] philosophy as he has aged. He has stated that he believes religion will eventually be as widely condemned as racism.{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/celebrity/actor-chris-odowd-says-religion-is-unacceptable-20140308-34ded.html|title=Actor Chris O'Dowd says religion is 'unacceptable'|work=The Sydney Morning Herald}} In April 2014, O'Dowd presented at [[Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS]] Easter Bonnet Competition with [[Leighton Meester]] and [[James Franco]], after raising donations at his [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] show ''[[Of Mice and Men (play)|Of Mice and Men]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/news/04-2014/bryan-cranston-james-franco-idina-menzel-and-more-_68349.html|title=Bryan Cranston, James Franco, Idina Menzel, and More in Highlights From the 2014 Easter Bonnet Competition|date=23 April 2014|work=TheaterMania.com}} On 1 February 2015, it was announced on Twitter that O'Porter gave birth to a son they named Arthur "Art" O'Porter a week earlier.{{cite news| url= http://www.evoke.ie/showbiz/its-a-boy-chris-odowd-and-dawn-oporter-announce-birth-of-son-art-and-joke-i-think-well-keep-him/|work=evoke.ie | title= 'It's a boy!' Chris O'Dowd and Dawn O'Porter announce birth of son Art and joke 'I think we'll keep him'| date=2 February 2015}} On 1 July 2017, O'Porter gave birth to their second son, Valentine. ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! '''Christian Schools International''' ('''CSI''') was established in 1920 and supports [[Christian school]] [[teacher]]s who want [[Bible]]-based [[textbooks]] for their classrooms, [[Principal (school)|principals]] and school administrators investigating [[Employee benefit|employee benefit plans]], Christian [[school board]] members seeking information about governance, and parents looking for a [[Christian]] school for their children.
Christian Schools International's mission is to advance Christian education and to support schools in their task of teaching students to know God and his world and to glorify him through obedient service.
The organization includes nearly 500 Christian schools in the United States and Canada, which employ approximately 10,000 teachers and enroll 100,000 students.
Christian Schools International publishes a magazine for parents, [http://www.csionline.org/christian_home_school ''Christian Home & School'']{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} and also assists schools through their [[accreditation]] programs focused on school improvement.
==External links== *[http://www.csionline.org/ Christian Schools International]
